div.head: Sand from river tellins and mussels from the river
div.ab: The long shells that can be found in fresh river waters, once calcined, makes an impalpable white sand, which moulds very neatly.

div.head: Freezing mercury
div.ab: It freezes, just as I tried, by boiling it one or two hours in a rather large iron posnet, putting in, for an ℥ of ☿, ii ℥ of verdet de and vitriol of saltpetre,ana, with sufficient quantity of old water from mareschaulx.

Or else, melt 4 ℥ of tin, & as it cools, purify it of its filth, which is on top, then, make a hole in it & put in there i ℥ of ☿ & it will come out like tin if you remelt it, but it will be breakable. And If you want to assay if it is tin or ☿, redden a shovel & put a small lump of your ingot on top. If it is tin, it will melt & stay, but if it is ☿, will quickly melt, then when crackling well, it will evaporate. One ought to freeze it in a spoon or in a hollow crucible, & make a moderately sized hole.
It can also be frozen, as I assayed, in aqua fortis which beforehand will have eaten a little silver. This one, mixed, makes tin & lead run.

div.head: Mixture
div.ab: Fine tin, frozen mercury with the smell of tin, looking glass tin, fine lead, as much of one as the other, makes a substance that melts very quickly, but breakable & white. I think that it would be good for solder. A long time to cool.
